description: Early Saxon origins of Lymington, the founding settlement called Limen tun by the marshy river.
Medieval governance and commerce: charters granted by William de Redvers, weekly markets and annual fairs.
Salt-making industry from medieval through 19th century: seawater evaporation and copper pan salterns.
Maritime trade and port activity: import of wine, export of cloth, and provisioning ships for war.
Conflict and warfare: French raids (1338, 1370, 1545), Hundred Years’ War, and Monmouth’s Rebellion.
19th century infrastructure and new industries: boat-building, railway arrival, gas lighting, piped water.
Demographics and civic life: population changes, founding of clubs, hospital opening, and museum.
Pennington Duel of 1814: Souper and Dieterich’s fatal confrontation on Pennington Common.
Foreign Military Depot: housing King’s German Legion and émigré regiments in Lymington during the Napoleonic Wars.
Souper’s trial and pardon: legal proceedings at Winchester Assizes for the duel-related death and subsequent clemency.
Campaign for clemency: petitions from military officers and Lymington residents advocating Souper’s pardon.
William Henry Souper: biographical background, military service records, and family details.
